awd_titl_txt: Strong Field Chemistry: Control Using the Radical Cation Launch State
awd_abstract_narration:
In this award, funded by the Chemical Structure, Dynamics and Mechanisms (CSDM-A) Program of the Division of Chemistry, Professor Robert Levis of Temple University and his graduate and undergraduate student researchers are doing experimental and computational studies to study the chemical reactivity of prototype molecules excited by ultrafast lasers. Prof. Levis and his group are attempting to understand the reactivity of molecules whose structures place them near so-called ?conical intersections?. These conical intersections are ubiquitous in a wide number of chemical contexts, but they remain poorly-understood except for the simplest chemical systems. These studies should help scientists better understand an important class of chemical reactions. Student researchers working on this project receive excellent training in experimental and computational physical chemistry. This project benefits from the collaboration with Dr. Spiridoula Matsika, a computational chemist at Temple University. 

Prof. Levis and his research group are conducting a series of experimental and modeling studies of the behavior of gas-phase alkylphenones undergoing strong-field excitation. The specific experiments to be carried out include: (1) spectroscopic studies of a series of alkylphenone molecules with strong-field mass spectrometry as a function of the wavelength of the excitation pulse; (2) investigations of the control of pre-ionized molecules to facilitate higher fidelity chemical control; (3) studies of the dynamics of alkylphenones in the vicinity of conical intersections using the radical cation launch state and strong fields to dress and Stark shift the pertinent potential surfaces; and (4) computational studies of the interaction of strong laser fields with polyatomic molecules to model the observations of experiment. Students working on this project receive excellent training in chemical physics that prepares them to become globally-engaged members of the technical workforce.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: TEMPLE UNIVERSITY-OF THE COMMONWEALTH SYSTEM OF HIGHER EDUCATION

por.por_cntn:
This is a summary of the project outcomes of NSF-funded research on Strong Field Chemistry: Control using the Radical Cation Launch State. During the tenure of CHE-0957694 this laboratory focused on expanding the understanding of strong-field chemistry, the chemistry of molecules exposed to the highly non-perturbative electromagnetic fields present in an amplified, femtosecond-duration laser pulse. The laser fields are strong enough to significantly modify the nuclear and electronic structure of a molecule during the interaction. The NSF-funded areas investigated during the last three years included the following topics with some 16 publications referencing NSF support since the termination of CHE-0957694. 

Intellectual Merit: We investigated the dynamics of wavepackets created using near-infrared laser fields on the ground state of acetophenone radical cations and employed this state as a launch state for electronic spectroscopy as well as control. The time-resolved transients were rationalized through calculation of the ground D0 and excited D1 through D9 ionic phenyl-acetyl torsional surfaces with a conical intersection at a torsional angle of 0o. Time-resolved measurements as a function of pump laser power revealed the presence of a second wavepacket oscillating on the D3 excited state surface. The degree of dissociation was observed to correlate with the ability to rotate about the phenyl-acetyl torsional mode in hydroxyl-substituted acetophenone molecules. 2- and 3-hydroxyacetophenone had limited dissociation compared to 4-hydroxyacetophenone and calculations revealed that the former did not rotate about the torsional bond while the latter did. Similarly, in methyl-substituted acetophenone, the 2- and 3-methyl acetophenone had reduced dissociation in comparison with 4- substitution because of the greater moment of inertia about the torsional axis. This discovery resulted from investigations of near-infrared, strong-field excitation of molecules after the construction of a tunable, filament-based optical parametric amplifier.

In a second line of research we continued our investigations of another strong-field process resulting in a universal, ambient pressure mass spectrometry method called laser electrospray mass spectrometry (LEMS). During the tenure of this award a number of investigations have been performed including resolving the structure of a proposed S-4 state in the photosynthetic oxygen evolving complex, demonstrating the classification of the manufacturer of five different black powder formulations with 100% classification accuracy and the perfect classification of gunshot residues. We began investigations of tissue imaging using LEMS and have submitted a manuscript describing mouse brain imaging. We have investigated the use of fiber laser vaporization of biological samples, and have probed internal energy distributions, discovered methods to increase charging of proteins, demonstrated excellent reproducibility using electrospray-deposited samples, and the isolation of the charge reduction process.

Broader Impacts: During the tenure of the previous NSF grants, undergraduate training has included the following more than 20 undergraduate students. More than 50% of these students were female, and of the students that have graduated, all but one are involved in science-related careers. Papers have been published from the work of undergraduate students. Recent graduate students working in this laboratory on NSF-funded research have gone on to careers in high technology science. Finally, spinoff research has resulted in new methods to detect and classify explosives, radioactive materials, and tissue phenotype and disease state using strong-field-matter interactions funded by NSF.

 


Last Modified: 05/01/2018
Modified by: Robert J Levis
